title: Projects Overview
intro: Some work I’ve designed, developed, and lovingly overthought. A mix of deep-dive case studies and mentioned projects. Not all my work is still live, some products are no longer avaialble due to business changes. I’ve shared the best available examples and case studies.

items.title: Rank & Style
items.headline: UX & Front-end Engineering Case study:
items.description: Scrappy under-resourced project quietly becomes the revenue driver

content.heading: Problem
paragraphs: When our company acquired this website, it was making almost all of its money through the newsletter. That was fine, but the business wanted to diversify revenue through SEO-driven affiliate marketing — which meant the site needed to rank well in search results and convert users through affiliate links and codes.

The problem was that the site wasn't built for search or affiliate monetisation at all. Structurally, technically, and content-wise, it didn’t meet the standards needed for performance, maintainability, accessibility, or SEO. We needed to change a newsletter-dependent website into a high-quality, search-optimised affiliate product, in 2 months with team of only 3 developers in total.

content.heading: Context
paragraphs: For affiliate marketing to really work, the site needed to perform well in Google search results. Search-led sites can be different to  content sites in terms of the heightened importance of clean semantic structure (H1, H2, H3 etc.), accessibility and clarity for both users and crawlers, page speed and performance, structured layout and content hierarchy which all play a big role in rankings. Search engines reward fast, credible and structured sites. We needed to first had to raise the technical quality of the site to meet our team's standards and Google's expectations.

During this project I worked heavily on the homepage and deals pages, focusing on improving page and element structure fixing heading hierarchy, implementing new designs and improving semantics. I also replaced the existing CMS WYSIWYG editor with TinyMCE to make life easier for our internal content team (although this was later changed again due to dependency vulnerabilities).

Alongside the technical work, I collaborated closely with product and design on A/B testing, teaching myself (and my team) how to use the platform and get reliable data. I communicated with the A/B Tasty team directly, analysed results with our designer, and feeding insights back into product decisions and priorities with our PM. So it was very much a cross-functional project.

content.heading: Outcome
paragraphs: Even though the business removed all development resources after just two months, within four months, this website became the top-profiting product out of 10+ products in the company portfolio. Affiliate monetisation successfully established through cleaner semantic structure, improved crawlability, maintainability, accessibility & performance in a team of just 3 developers. The team also benefited through learning more about A/B Testing together, as well as our internal content managers experience with the CMS WYSIWYG vastly improved.

items.title: e-wolf
items.headline: Freelance Brand Design: What happens when a website needs a brand first?
items.description: What happens when a website needs a brand first?

content.heading: Problem
paragraphs: The client initially approached us for a website redesign, but there was very little existing brand identity to design from. They urgently needed print-ready marketing material for an upcoming event. Without a clear brand system, any new website or collateral risked looking inconsistent and unprofessional and  repeatedly going over design decisions with each new project. We needed to turn a website request into a sustainable design foundation that could support both print and digital work going forward.

content.heading: Context
paragraphs: e-WOLF develops custom battery systems. Their work is highly technical and innovative, but their marketing material had never been professionally designed. The brand needed to communicate: reliability and safety, engineering precision, modern innovation, sustainability and forward-thinking We also had a practical constraint: deliver event-ready collateral quickly, without sacrificing brand quality. To reduce risk and deliver value quickly, we broke the project into phases. We started by We creating a scalable visual system from the ground up, in the first phase. Decisions were documented into a corporate guideline that the client could reuse for future work, including for a planned website redesign. Using the guidelines, we designed print material. I contribute to all phases of this project including strategy and implementation, contributing to branding, graphic and UI design.

content.heading: Project Phases
paragraphs: Phase 1 focused on brand foundations including colour palette, typography system, icon style, imagery direction, grid and spacing rules, and core UI components.
Phase 2 produced corporate design guidelines to ensure consistency across future work.
Phase 3 delivered marketing collateral for the event including pamphlets, flyers, large-format banners and layout templates for ongoing use.

content.heading: Outcome
paragraphs: The result was a cohesive, reusable brand foundation that e-WOLF can now use across print and digital communication. A full corporate design guideline now enables consistent design decisions going forward.. The client was delivered event-ready marketing material that matched the quality and credibility of the company’s engineering work. A nice surprise in this project was directly seeing improved stakeholder confidence - the marketing manager shared positive feedback and pictures of printed designs in use. The project created a scalable design foundation that can now be used for future deliverables, including the upcoming website redesign.

This project was a great example of how design strategy prevents future chaos: instead of jumping straight into a website redesign without brand structure, we created a foundation first. This is sure to save time, improve consistency, and increase delivery speed of future projects.

items.title: Slickdeals
items.headline: Front-end Case Study: From zero to launch: building a promo codes site for speed and scale
items.description: From zero to launch: building a promo codes site for speed and scale

content.heading: Problem
paragraphs: I was one of two front-end developers responsible for the initial build of multiple pages within the /promo-codes subdirectory of Slickdeals. We created a new theme from scratch to avoid the limitations of existing legacy themes and to set a clean foundation for future sites built on top of the same codebase.

The goal was to create a robust theming system and reusable templates using variables and default styles, reducing repetition and ensuring consistent UI patterns across multiple page types. Delivery was due in under three weeks, with the added pressure that this build formed part of a pitch to win the client.

content.heading: Context
paragraphs: The long-term strategy for this site was scalability and search-led growth. The business model relied on traffic coming from Google and monetisation through affiliate links and promo codes, meaning the platform needed to support a large number of store and category pages, SEO-friendly structure and crawlability, fast load times and strong performance, UX patterns that help users scan quickly and take action.

Visitors were typically not brand-loyal users, they arrived with a specific goal (finding the best deal quickly), low patience for friction, and high expectations of trust and clarity. We therefore focused on consistent UI patterns and performance-conscious front-end development from day one.

content.heading: Outcome
paragraphs: We delivered a clean, modern front-end foundation under a tight deadline, including the core templates and theming system required to support scale.
The shop page was completed in under three weeks, providing one of the key entry points for SEO traffic and conversion.
Although the client didn’t sign immediately, they returned approximately a year later and the project was revived by other team members.
This validated the strength and reusability of the foundation we created.

items.title: Portfolio
items.headline: UX & Development Case Study: Designing & building this portfolio
items.description: Designing & building a personal portfolio as a UX engineer

content.heading: Problem
paragraphs: I work in the wonderful digital world, but I don't have a website. I am trying to sell digital experiences without having my own.
My work lives in scattered pockets: LinkedIn here, Behance there, maybe a CV floating around. I need a space to communicate my full story professionally and something unique to me.
Most of what I create is shaped around my clients' brands, so there's no central corner of the internet that fully reflects my creative brain, process, and personality.
I want a single, beautifully designed home for my work, story, case studies, recommendations and experience — a place where people can actually experience what I do, not just read about it.

content.heading: Objectives
paragraphs: Create a home where people can easily explore my professional world — clear, accessible, and reflective of my personality.
Visitors should be able to feel the experience I have designed, not just view content.
Success looks like contact-form emails landing in my inbox, stars growing on my GitHub repositories, genuine client enquiries, and users staying, scrolling, and engaging instead of bouncing away.

content.heading: Audience
paragraphs: My portfolio is designed both for humans and automated screening tools such as ATS platforms, HR screening tools, crawlers and AI summarisation systems.
For machines, the site prioritises semantic HTML, clear headings, structured content, descriptive URLs, alt text, crawlable content and SEO-friendly terminology aligned with CV tools and job titles.
Explicit outcomes and metrics are valuable for recruiters and summarisation tools, while case studies provide SEO value and often serve as the first contact point with my portfolio.
For humans, the design considers fast scanning, visual judgement, emotional trust, and personality — confirming relevance quickly before encouraging deeper exploration into case studies.
The tone, visuals and experience aim to support hiring managers and founders in assessing not just skills, but communication style, trust and working compatibility.

sections.heading: Context
paragraphs: Runs a small tech business with limited time. Their in-house design and tech team does not have capacity for additional projects.
Looking for a freelancer because they need extra hands at times. A full-time position is not necessary right now.
Agencies feel expensive and impersonal. Searches on Google include terms like 'UX portfolio South Africa', 'UX freelancer', and 'UX freelance Portfolio Cape Town'.

sections.heading: Goals
bullets: Understand quickly who this person is and what they can deliver
Feel confident handing over work and access

sections.heading: Behaviour & tools
bullets: Looks for social proof (testimonials, past work)

sections.heading: Pain points
bullets: Agencies being too expensive and impersonal
Fear of being overcharged or misunderstood
Fear of mismatch with person and business

sections.heading: Addressing pain points
bullets: Clear, friendly language that feels human and trustworthy
Simple explanations of services and process
Visible real-world examples through case studies
Future video content to communicate personality

sections.heading: Context
paragraphs: Reviews a high volume of applications daily within an Applicant Tracking System.
Filters, ranks and compares candidates before reaching out.
Finds portfolio links inside CVs or ATS profiles and focuses on structured, clear information rather than heavy visuals.

sections.heading: Behaviour & tools
bullets: Spends brief time on the website

sections.heading: Pain points
bullets: Having to search in different places for information

sections.heading: Addressing pain points
bullets: Easy scanning with highlighted roles, skills and experience

content.heading: Context
paragraphs: Although the site is small, it acts as my primary technical proof and professional presence — with front-end, design and UX being equally important.
The portfolio needed to be clean, readable, modern and easy to use, while still expressing personality and avoiding a boring or generic feel.
A major constraint was time: treating the portfolio as a real product with deadlines, shipping a strong v1 quickly to support applications and client outreach.
The site was designed to grow with me — allowing new case studies, projects and experience to be added over time.

content.heading: Outcome
paragraphs: The result is a strong v1 portfolio that brings my work into one central place and demonstrates my end-to-end UX engineering approach.
Success is measured through recruiter and founder responses, increased contact requests, and how effectively the site supports professional opportunities.
Feedback and engagement metrics before and after launch provide insight into continuous improvements.
